naeb headquarters
juft 6 1355
p»
Network Acceptance Subcommittee ^ June lf 1955
Hugh Mix, Jack Westbrook, John Holt
Re: "Roots of Jazz”
Gentlemen:
Afraid "Roots of Jazz" is too esoteric for my blood...and this
quarter is ardent in its appreciation of such music*
For years disc jockeys et al have been solemnly tracing
the roots of jazz, attaching to it a social significance
beyond its social significance* There are few people
who can go into a rhapsodic trance over the thin, ancient
music of Jelly Roll Morton, etc.--thats strictly for the
real cats. Brubeck and some of the moderns certainly
have numberous intense followers, but here again, the
number is limited. I’m certain that most of us can
produce good jazz programs without a lot of the narrative
claptrap that goes into programs of this ilk. "Roots of
Jazz” has other flaws in addition to what I consider its
inherent ones. The commentators are unskilled and there
are s*xious gaps in continuity, etc. I fear this fifth
really flatted for me. gg.
Jim Slack
Network Acceptance Subcommittee
